comments.author: Alessandra
comments.content: I agree, soggy tabbouleh is not nice! Good one!

comments.author: Chris
comments.content: Better yet, skip boiling the bulghur and let it soak in the chopped tomatoes. That's how we've always done it. :) http://www.weheartfood.com/2007/07/tabbouleh.html

comments.author: Renee
comments.content: Yes, it totally works to use quinoa for gluten free tabbouleh. Love it!

comments.author: Xiaolu @ 6 Bittersweets
comments.content: Never tried making tabbouleh myself.  It's a nice refreshing dish I really need to try.  Thanks for the recipe!

comments.author: Ordinary Blogger (Rivki Locker)
comments.content: I am a big tabbouleh fan but never knew to wring out the grains. This sounds like a great technique. Thanks for sharing!

comments.author: Neel | Learn Food Photography
comments.content: This is great. I love veggie food and this is a great blog. Thank you for sharing your recipes.

comments.author: susan
comments.content: I'm ashamed to publicly admit I usually made the crappy Western modified version but, am happy to report I'll be making this authentic and delicious version from now on. Thanks!

comments.author: Judith Kingsbury
comments.content: I always wondered why I didn't care for tabouleh! It wasn't real, and neither is the version on my site. Your tabouleh recipe sounds divine, and I just happen to have some primo parsley & mint in my garden. Looking forward to trying this tabouleh, and will be sure to pass it on. Thanks!

comments.author: Jenn L @ Peas & Crayons
comments.content:
Good call on the quinoa & I totally agree on america over-doing the grains.... we've got to cool our jets and get back to veggies, people! =)

great recipe! Can't wait to try it out soon!

xoXOxo

comments.author: Quay Po Cooks
comments.content: This is a refreshing and healthy dish.. nice photo.  Thanks for the tips on wringing the soaked bulghur out in a dish towel.

comments.author: Phil B
comments.content: When I was in Israel I visited my friend's Druze village where we had an amazing meal in a local restaurant. She passed me this bowl of chopped greens and said it was tabbouleh. I took my fork and lifted it up to see where the Bulgar was -- she was so confused! There, it's just a chopped herb salad eaten with pita. What culture does the bulgar aspect come from?

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: No bulghar at all? Now that I haven't seen. Everywhere that I'm familiar with in the Middle East, it definitely is a salad of green, but it does have about, oh, maybe 20% bulghur by volume. Just goes to show you how food names are always changing, evolving and localizing. Thanks for sharing!

comments.author: Jennifer (Delicieux)
comments.content: I love tabbouleh and have made it a few times recently.  The recipe I use isn't too dissimilar to yours.  I've never soaked the bulghur wheat in boiling water.  I simply rinse it under cold water in a colander and then let it dry on some paper towel.  I will try your method next time I make tabbouleh.  Thanks for the tip :D

comments.author: Rachel
comments.content: My mom and I have a recipe similar to this, however we swap mint for cilantro and lemon for lime. We jokingly call it Texas Tabbouleh since we live in Austin and here cilantro and lime are constant ingredients. If you feel the way I do about mint, cilantro is a delicious alternative.

comments.author: anh
comments.content: This is one of my favourite salad, ever! I also find that the younger and tender the parsley leaves the better it is :)

comments.author: Spanish Steps
comments.content: Thanks for the real Tabbouleh recipe! Just an observation..."6 tablespooons thinly sliced green onions" has one extra "o" :)

comments.author: Spanish Steps
comments.content: You are welcome! But I just found another typo: "tomatmoes" from your directions #3. I noticed when I copied the recipe to a word document.
